I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In Papua New Guinea (PNG), more than 90% of the population (mostly rural dwellers) 
has no electricity. In urban centers, the power supply is often unreliable. The country’s medium 
term  development  strategy  (MTDS)  2005–20101  recognizes  energy  and  power  as  critical 
ingredients for development and poverty reduction. The strategy invites the Government to 
assist the disadvantaged to “lift themselves out of poverty by improving basic services such as 
water and electricity.”  
 
2.  Assistance to the country’s power sector was included in ADB’s Country Strategy and 
Program (2006–2010)2 for PNG and confirmed during the 2006 Country Programming Mission. 
In  February  2007,  a  technical  assistance  (TA)  fact-finding  mission  was  fielded3  An 
understanding was reached on the TA’s purpose, key activities, consultants’ terms of reference, 
cost estimates and financing, and implementation arrangements. The design and monitoring 
framework is provided in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  The Energy Sector 
3.  PNG  is  well-endowed  with  natural  resources,  including  energy  reserves,  but  the 
country’s formidable geography and the high cost of developing infrastructure have constrained 
their exploitation. The outcome is a dual economy and society, marked by a few enclaves of 
industrialization surrounded by widely diffused poverty. The high population growth (2.3% per 
annum) and urbanization rate have increased difficulties for the country.  
 
4.  The challenge is for PNG to use its energy resources to help reverse a negative spiral 
and to move the country towards more sustainable social and economic development. This 
vision is articulated in the national energy policy, which aims “to diligently promote and facilitate 
the development of the energy sector in order to ensure the availability, reliability, affordability 
and  efficient  use  of  energy.”  Therefore,  social  development  occurs  by  utilizing  energy  for 
economic activity, through an environmentally sound manner.4  
 
5.  PNG has substantial deposits of hydrocarbons. Oil production facilities at Kutubu, Gobe 
and Moran produce an average of 50,000 barrels a day. Most of the oil is exported through a 
273 kilometer pipeline and an offshore marine terminal. About 145 million cubic meters (m3) of 
natural gas is produced annually at the Hides gas field for the Porgera mine’s power plant. 
Almost all the gas arising from oil production is re-injected into the oil-producing reservoirs, 
although a limited amount is flared for operational requirements. 
 
6.  PNG’s  oil  reserves  are  relatively  modest  and  declining,  but  its  gas  reserves  are 
substantial. The remaining proved recoverable oil reserves are estimated at 80 million barrels. 
The recoverable proved and probable natural gas reserves are estimated at 428 billion m3, 
equivalent to 3.02 billion barrels of oil. Limited and declining oil production potential makes it 
essential that PNG’s natural gas fields be developed to maintain an inflow of foreign exchange.

7.  In order to supply gas demand in eastern Australia, a proposed $2.5 billion PNG Gas 
Project was designed to commercialize 5.6 billion m3 of natural gas. However, the cost of the 
project  dramatically  increased  during  2006,  particularly  in  respect  of  the  gas  distribution 
pipelines in Australia. This caused the entire scheme to be shelved in late January 2007. The 
companies involved in the PNG Gas Project have now turned their attention to the production of 
liquefied natural gas (LNG) for export to Asian and other markets. Such a project might yield 
annual revenues of about $200 million to $300 million5 for the PNG economy for 30 years. The 
proposed onshore gas pipeline to a coastal LNG facility would be managed to retain flexibility 
for  third  parties  to  supply  different  areas  and  customers  in  accordance  with  government-
approved access principles.  
 
B.  The Power Sector 
8.  Natural gas could alleviate the problem of PNG’s limited power supply, but it is not the 
only solution. The country is rich in renewable energy resources suitable for power production, 
in particular hydropower potential. PNG has more than 15,000 MW hydropower potential. The 
possibility of building a $2 billion (60 meter high) dam to produce 1,800 MW of power at Wabo 
on the Purari River to serve power aluminum smelting and to feed the power grid is being 
investigated. Coconut plantations are widely spread throughout PNG and may be a potential 
source  of  power  as  coconut-based  bio-diesel  becomes  a  viable  option.  It  has  also  been 
suggested that coal could be imported from Australia and Indonesia. There is no single solution. 
The  geography  of  PNG  calls  for  articulated  power  sector  optimization  based  on  small 
disaggregated markets.  
 
9.  The  Independent  Consumer  and  Competition  Commission  (ICCC),  the  regulator,  is 
seeking to increase investments and competition in the power sector in order to increase the 
quantity and quality of the power supply. The aim is to reduce the environmental, economic and 
social costs associated with emissions, frequent power outages and limited access. However, 
the ICCC does not have the capacity to conduct technical regulatory work. It has therefore 
delegated  safety  and  standards  regulatory  functions  (on  a  yearly  renewable  basis)  to  the 
government-owned PNG Power Ltd (PPL). 
 
10.  PPL  supplies  power  to  Port  Moresby  and  26  other  urban  centers  through  19 
independent  power  systems.  Its  present  generating  capacity  is  153  MW  (80  MW  in  Port 
Moresby) for total energy sales of 742 GWh (316 GWh in Port Moresby). PPL, formerly the 
Electricity Commission, used to be the sole generator, transmitter and distributor of electricity in 
the country. In 1999, an independent power producer, Hanjung Power Ltd, negotiated the 
production  and  sale  of  power  to  the  grid  within  a  15-year  build-operate-transfer  (BOT) 
arrangement. However, the present electricity tariff of about $0.15 per kilowatt hour (kWh) is 
hardly sufficient to cover the cost of the diesel oil needed to produce power in Port Moresby. In 
rural areas the cost of diesel alone can be three times the tariff, or more. Since 2003, PPL has 
been earmarked for privatization and a new private commercial operator, PNG Sustainable 
Energy Ltd (SEL), is beginning to enter the sector.   
 
11.   The  Energy  Division  of  the  Department  of  Petroleum  and  Energy  (ED-DPE)  is 
responsible for the rural electrification program. The provincial governments have responsibility 
for maintaining the Government’s stand-alone rural generation facilities (C-Centers). There are 
several other power suppliers. Churches and missions provide electricity to nearby areas while 
some mine, industrial and agricultural enclaves supply free electricity to nearby villages. PPL

has an ongoing program of extending the urban grids to sell electricity to rural communities 
close to the grid. SEL is also actively entering the sector. The World Bank is assisting SEL with 
a Solar Lantern Project for teachers, and it is discussing possible assistance to finance mini-
hydro schemes in rural areas. 
 
C.  The Power Sector Development Plan 
12.  Several studies have been produced on the conditions and challenges in PNG’s power 
sector, including a study of energy sector and rural electrification assisted by the World Bank6 
and PPL’s National and Provincial Ten Year Power Development Plan.7 ED-DPE has drafted 
the overall country energy and power policy framework.8 A national electricity industry policy 
task force has been created to chart the country’s electricity needs in accordance with the 
MTDS priorities. The Government has asked ED-DPE to complement its draft policy with a 
sector master plan. This is consistent with the Paris Declaration’s9 partnership commitment to 
translate national development strategies into prioritized result-oriented operational programs.  
 
13.  The development plan requires a comprehensive and consultation-based power sector 
analysis combined with a stakeholders’ diagnostic analysis to provide a more holistic view of the 
sector’s challenges and opportunities. The plan will also provide a power sector operational 
program with recommended actions, timetables and costing.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The  long-term  objective  of  the  TA  is  to  increase  the  availability  of  a  reliable  and 
sustainable power supply at reasonable cost. The purpose is to assist the Government to 
examine  issues  and  options  to  promote  and  facilitate  the  provision  of  reliable,  safe  and 
affordable access to an efficient electrical power supply for PNG. 
 
15.  The main outputs of the TA will include the following. 
 
(i)  Assessment of power sector demand and supply. Building upon the findings 
of previous studies of the sector and the knowledge of the ED-DPE, the TA will 
undertake research and detailed consultations to (a) provide an overview of 
sector demand and supply, (b) assist in identifying and addressing the main 
information gaps, (c) identify ways of maximizing renewable energy production 
and energy efficiency to reduce the overall cost of providing power, and (d) 
discuss  the  main  findings  with  the  Government  and  private  sector  and  civil 
society representatives. 
  
(ii)  Review of power sector policy, legislation, regulations and procedures. 
New technologies are emerging and private sector operators show interest not 
only  in  supplying  the  more  viable  load  centers,  but  also  in  building  and/or

needs review, which should include consideration of the appropriate assignment 
of responsibility for technical regulation. The TA will also assist in drafting any

(iii)  Diagnostic  analysis  of  sector  entities  and  related  binding  constraints. 
Several entities are engaged in the sector. PPL supplies electricity to the main 
centers. ED-DPE, local governments, churches, non-government organizations 
(NGOs) and private operators commonly serve rural areas. The TA will identify 
the capacity of stakeholders, issues, binding constraints and lessons learned. It 
will  discuss  recommendations  and  propose  concrete  steps  to  improve  and 
address  sector  efficiency  and  efficacy,  environmental  and  social  issues, 
consumer protection and sustainability.  
 
(iv)  Power demand forecast and least-cost supply development plan. PNG’s 
expected power demand and potential supply is geographically diverse. The TA 
will  assist  in  (a)  forecasting  power  demand,  (b)  identifying  the  least-cost 
development  program  that  facilitates  economic  development  and  poverty 
reduction, and (c) undertaking preliminary technical, economic, financial, social 
and  environmental  analysis  for  prioritized  investment  requirements  in  the 
development program. 
 
(v)  Action-oriented and monitorable power sector operational program. The 
power sector operational program will define the key and practical tasks that 
need  to  be  done,  the  task  responsibilities  and  a  schedule.  The  operational 
program  will  be  action-oriented,  realistic  and practical.  It  will  also  advise  on 
potential roles for ADB, the private sector and civil society, and include all the 
information and tasks required to undertake coordination among donors.10  
 
(vi)  Capacity building. During the TA implementation, the consultant will maximize 
on-the-job  training  and  technology  transfer,  particularly  by  working  in  close 
consultation and collaboration with ED-DPE counterpart staff. The outcome of 
such interaction will be assessed, and this approach will be emphasized to the 
consultant at the outset.  
 
(vii)  Results dissemination. The results and findings of the TA will be presented and 
discussed with the main stakeholders and widely published in an easy-to-read 
format and in the local language(s), as required. The main recommendations 
may become the basis for an information paper to the National Executive Council 
(the Cabinet) and subsequently a white paper for presentation to the Parliament. 
The consultant’s final report containing the main issues and concerns raised and 
solutions identified will be widely circulated and posted on the internet. 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
10  Several donors are involved in the sector, including ADB, the Australian Overseas Aid Program (AusAID), the PNG 
Sustainable  Development  Program  (PNGSDP),  the  Pacific  Islands  Applied  Geoscience  Commission 
(SOPAC), the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the World Bank. Donations are mainly for

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.   The  TA  will  build  on  the  findings  and  achievements  generated  by  previous  sector 
studies and assistance. The TA activities will include assisting the Government to (i) review 
available literature and documentation; (ii) identify the present energy and power demand and 
forecast demand; (iii) assess the supply options and assist their optimization; (iv) review the 
pertinent policy, legislation, regulations and procedures, and establish their appropriateness and 
any deficiencies; (v) perform a diagnosis of the sector entities and constraints; (vi) prepare three 
to five power sector development pre-feasibility studies for prioritized investments; (vii) draft a 
power sector operational program; (viii) facilitate the coordination of donors; (ix) enhance human 
resources capacity; (x) increase the awareness of stakeholders on the benefits of reform; (xi) 
facilitate the support of policy makers; and (xii) disseminate the main findings and lessons 
learned. 
 
C.       Cost and Financing 
17.   The TA is estimated to cost $630,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $500,000 equivalent 
on a grant basis from ADB’s Japan Special Fund, financed by the Government of Japan. The 
Government of PNG will contribute $130,000 equivalent to finance counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, communication, local transport and consultations and awareness facilitation. 
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The ED-DPE will be the executing agency (EA) of the TA. The EA will facilitate the 
collection of all available relevant information. The EA will recruit and appoint a project manager 
with qualifications acceptable to ADB on terms of reference prepared by the EA and reviewed 
by ADB. The Director, ED-DPE, will provide overall guidance to the project. It is proposed that a 
steering committee be chaired by the Department of National Planning and Rural Development 
and include representatives of ED-DPE, the Department of Provincial and Local Government 
Affairs, PPL, the PNG Gas Office, SEL, private sector representatives, NGOs and users. The 
committee will provide overall supervision and help to ensure adequate cooperation from local 
government bodies, governments and NGOs active in the power sector, as well as users and 
beneficiaries.  The  Consultative  Implementation  and  Monitoring  Council  (CMIC)  might  be 
considered for the role of secretariat to the steering committee.  
 
19.  ADB will engage about 14 person-months of international and 10 person-months of 
domestic consultant services. The services will be recruited through a consulting firm selected 
through the quality and cost-based selection (QCBS) method with quality cost ratio of 80:20 and 
based on the submission of simplified technical proposals, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Procurement of equipment 
and software will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time) and will be handed over to the EA upon completion of the TA. The 
detailed  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  given  in  Appendix  3.  The  TA  will  be 
implemented  over  20  months,  with  services  to  be  rendered  on  an  intermittent  basis.  It  is 
expected to begin in October 2007 and be completed by June 2009.

6   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Papua New Guinea for the Power Sector Development Plan, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Terms of Reference for the Consultants 
1.  The consultants shall ensure that all works and outputs under the technical assistance 
(TA)  are  fully  compliant  with  all  relevant  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  policies  and 
guidelines. The consultants’ work should include, but will not be limited to, the following. 
 
2.  The  power  sector  specialist  and  team  leader1  (international,  5  person-months)  will 
undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Prepare the detailed work program and implementation schedule for the TA, and 
coordinate the work of the consultants on the team.  
(ii)  Review available studies relating to the energy and power sector, and prepare a 
summary of the current status of resources and the sector requirements.  
(iii)  Assist in identifying and addressing the main information gaps and review them. 
(iv)  Identify ways of maximizing renewable energy production and energy efficiency 
to reduce the overall cost of producing power. 
(v)  In coordination with the TA for implementation of the public enterprises’ public 
expenditure review and rationalization, explore the possibility of private sector 
participation in the power sector.  
(vi)  Identify project opportunities and prepare concept paper proposals on renewable 
energy and energy efficiency projects for financing/cofinancing by ADB, Global 
Environment Facility (GEF), Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) and other 
funding sources. 
(vii)  Assist the power sector participatory review, including stakeholders’ analysis, 
problem analysis, objective analysis and alternative analysis. 
(viii)  Review the environmental policy, legislation and regulation for energy projects. 
(ix)  Review the technical and commercial regulatory regime for its appropriateness 
and identify any deficiencies. 
(x)  Assist the Energy Division of the Department of Petroleum and Energy (EPD-
DPE) in preparing an action-oriented and time-bound power sector operational 
program with baseline data, monitorable indicators and accountable entities. 
(xi)  Prepare a detailed and comprehensive investment program. 
(xii)  Prepare  three  to  five  power  sector  pre-feasibility  studies  for  the  priority 
investments proposed, including preliminary environmental and social analysis. 
(xiii)  Prepare quantitative estimates of the environmental cost for the selected priority 
projects. 
(xiv)  Assist EPD-DPE to prepare a white paper for Cabinet consideration and tabling 
in Parliament on power sector reform and expansion criteria and procedures. 
(xv)  Maximize on-the-job training and technology transfer, particularly by undertaking 
the task in close consultation and collaboration with ED-DPE counterpart staff.  
(xvi)  Assist ADB in assessment of the training transfer outcome for ED-DPE and other 
stakeholders.  
(xvii)  Prepare recommendations for capacity building for the implementation of the 
power  sector  development  plan,  including  project  and  environmental 
management.

(xix)  Prepare terms of reference and outline a feasible implementation schedule for

sector expansion plan. 
(xx)  Undertake any reasonable requests made by ADB associated with the TA. 
 
3.  The  power  system  planner  and  economist2  (international,  2  person-months)  will 
undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Assess the power system expansion plan, capacity for project implementation, 
and methods for prioritizing projects.  
(ii)  Assist in identifying and addressing the power sector’s main information gaps, 
identify areas for improving power system planning and assess the requirements 
of specific areas. 
(iii)  Identify  feasible  technical  options,  including  ways  of  maximizing  renewable 
energy production and energy efficiency to reduce the overall cost of producing 
power. 
(iv)  Prepare and confirm detailed cost estimations for the core subprojects. 
(v)  Prepare selection criteria for the least-cost design of subprojects to be funded 
under the investment program. 
(vi)  Determine environment and land acquisition issues and costs, as required, under 
the long-term development plan. 
(vii)  Review the present lifeline tariff for consumers with the lowest incomes and their 
ability to pay. 
(viii)  Identify  an  appropriate  recurrent  maintenance  program,  including 
recommendations for funding maintenance of the proposed facilities. 
(ix)  Prepare  the  financial  and  economic  analysis  of  the  least-cost  expansion 
program. 
(x)  Prepare financial and economic analysis for the prioritized projects subject to the 
pre-feasibility study. 
(xi)  Ensure that the environmental costs are included in the financial and economic 
analysis of the projects. 
(xii)  Review the present tariff-setting mechanisms and tariff adjustment to fuel costs 
and foreign exchange rate changes. 
 
4.  The participatory and social development expert (international, 3 person-months) must 
have (i) extensive experience in participatory planning, (ii) qualifications in social development 
and facilitation techniques, and (iii) extensive experience with, and knowledge of, ADB’s design 
and monitoring framework (DMF) approach or “goal-oriented project planning.” Professional 
experience in the power sector is an added advantage. The specific duties and responsibilities 
of the specialist will include the following.  
 
(i)  Using  the  DMF  approach,  design  a  stakeholders’  participation  program 
incorporating  and  covering  (a)  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  activities,  inputs, 
                                                 
2 The specialist must have at least 5 years’ experience in power system planning and qualification in economic 
analysis of power projects.

12  Appendix 3 
performance indicators and targets, data sources and monitoring mechanisms, 
and  assumptions  and  risks;  and  (b)  techniques  assuring  a  high  level  of 
participation. 
(ii)  Assist  the  preparation  and  discussion  of  the  situation  assessment,  including 
stakeholders’ analysis and problem analysis. 
(iii)  Assist  the  preparation  and  discussion  of  the  solution  development  analysis, 
including objective analysis, alternative analysis and project strategy. 
(iv)  Assist the determination of the land acquisition issues and costs, as required, 
under the long-term development plan. 
(v)  Review the present lifeline tariff for consumers with the lowest incomes and their 
ability to pay. 
(vi)  Facilitate a detailed discussion of the potential impacts of the implementation of 
the operational program, particularly on women and the poor, and identify ways 
to make the power sector work for the poor. 
(vii)  Prepare a poverty profile of the people affected by the implementation of the 
operational program, and assess the pro-poor impact in line with ADB’s poverty 
reduction strategy. 
(viii)  Prepare  a  consultation  and  participation  plan  and  strategy  involving  users, 
landowners, beneficiaries and affected communities, and develop a consultation 
mechanism and public awareness program.  
(ix)  Facilitate the stakeholders’ awareness campaign, and document stakeholders’ 
meetings and feedback on the project’s design and monitoring framework.  
 
5.  Short-term international consultants (international, 4 person-months), identified during 
TA implementation, will be engaged to assist the team leader and ADB staff. The specific skill 
requirements will be identified during TA implementation (possibly in the inception phase). The 
consultants will mainly act as technical support for the team leader in implementing the TA. The 
development  plan  involves  an  extremely  broad  area  of  expertise.  The  additional  expertise 
required  can  cover  policy  and  power-related  regulation  and  legislation,  energy  technology 
review, environmental and social impact assessments, and private sector participation in power 
generation.   
6.  The social analysis and community development expert3 (domestic, 10 person-months) 
will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Assist  the  participatory  and  social  development  expert  in  organizing  the 
stakeholders’ participation and awareness campaign.  
(ii)  Facilitate collection of the information required and consult relevant officials from 
the  Government  and  other  organizations  to  supplement  available  secondary 
data. 
(iii)  Assist in the preparation of a gender-disaggregated poverty profile of the people 
affected by the implementation of the operational program; assess the pro-poor 
impact  in  line  with  ADB’s  poverty  reduction  strategy;  provide  a  detailed 
discussion  of  the  potential  impacts  of  the  implementation  of  the  operational 
program, particularly on the poor; and identify ways to make the power sector 
work for the poor. 
(iv)  Assist the preparation of a consultation and participation plan and participation 
strategy  and  define  the  nature  and  level  of  stakeholders’  cooperation  and 
coordination.  
                                                 
3 The specialist must have extensive experience in community development in PNG or in the region.

Appendix 3           13 
(v)  Facilitate public acceptance of the operational program; assist in the preparation 
of an initial social assessment and identify any potential adverse effects; and 
prepare  a  social  analysis  following  ADB  guidelines  and  an  analysis  of  the 
impacts on indigenous peoples and appropriate socioeconomic monitoring and 
management plans to be implemented.  
(vi)  Facilitate  the  conduct  of  awareness  campaigns  and  capacity  building,  and 
conduct  stakeholders'  participation,  ensuring  full  participation  of  women  and 
vulnerable groups at all stages of the TA. 
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
7.  The following reports will be prepared by the consultants and submitted simultaneously 
to EPD-DPE and ADB, in three hard copies each and in electronic format, Microsoft Word as 
well as Adobe Acrobat (pdf) files. 
 
(i)  A brief inception report 6 weeks from the commencement of services detailing 
initial findings and recommendations for the future direction of the TA. 
(ii)  Brief  monthly  reports  summarizing  the  progress  of  work,  major  findings  and 
notation of problem areas such as lack of data and other impediments that could 
hamper the TA. 
(iii)  A mid-term report 1 year from the TA commencement date.  
(iv)  A draft final report incorporating the findings of the TA. 
(v)  A final report, based on the draft final report, incorporating the comments and 
proposed changes received on the draft final report. The electronic copy will be 
prepared in a format ready to be posted on ADB’s website.
